I'll open up a separate issue to address the nesting issue, once that is fixed, this issue should be resolved too.

Hi, I have just pushed a fix for the nested action issue. Now using
```dosini
label-focused = %{A1:i3-msg workspace back_and_forth:}  %index%  %{A}
label-focused-padding = 0
```
in your config should work as expected.
*Note:* You need to set the padding to 0 because the padding is not part of the label and thus there would be no action block on the padding only on the text itself.

title: Make IPC module accept arbitrary text over the socket
body:
Currently, to extend polybar, we can either use the script module or the IPC module. The script module allows to do anything, but you have to spawn a new process. With the `tail` directive, it's possible to avoid spawning processes at a regular interval. But, a distinct process is still needed (and it eats some memory). With the IPC module, you can trigger an update from another process, but this will run a script to make the update (and it eats CPU and battery).

Something between the two could be useful: extend the IPC module to allow sending arbitrary text to be displayed instead of just a hook number.

I am willing to implement this, but as there is already some issues around the IPC module, I would like to gather some feedback and agreement around such a feature.

See #1127 and #1670 which are somewhat related.
author: vincentbernat

comments.body:
I think there has been demand for this in the past as well and I think this would fit in polybar.

I do have some thoughts:

* Polybar already has a one-way FIFO it uses for IPC, we should also use it for this feature. In fact, we could (and probably should) just create a module action where the data is the text sent to the module.
* I'm not sure if we should extend the IPC module, it's probably better to have a new module dedicated for this. Unless you have an argument why this would integrate well with the IPC module.

title: Generic/Xmonad-specific window restacker
body:
I'm using xmonad as my wm.
In some use cases, starting polybar after xmonad put polybar above windows, even with the correct configuration on both programs (without xmonad ``avoidStruts`` hook).
In xmobar, the ``option lowerOnStart = True`` is used to fix this.

Solution: Add `lowerOnStart` options support to polybar, which, if set `true`, will start polybar on the bottom of window stack.

ArchLinux
polybar 3.4.3
Features: +alsa +curl +i3 +mpd +network(libnl) +pulseaudio +xkeyboard
author: tjbrn

comments.body:
Polybar has the `wm-restack` option to do this. However, it only supports bspwm and i3.

I think an xmonad specific restacker or a generic one that just lowers polybar to the bottom of the stack would be a good solution here.

If anyone wants to tackle this, the place to add this new restacker is the `bar::restack_window` function in `bar.cpp`

In the mean time one could create a hacky solution using a tool like `xdo` to lower polybar after you start it:

```sh
xdo lower $(xwininfo -name polybar-xmonad_DP-0 | rg 'window id' | cut -d ' ' -f4)
```

Find the name of each polybar instance by running `xwininfo` with no args and clicking on it (in my case they are called `polybar-xmonad_HDMI-0` etc.)
Do this for each of your polybar instances.

title: [Feature request] Environment field in custom scripts
body:
## Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
I have a set of scripts which I use in my polybar config. I have a wrapper script to format them correctly; so i usually call them using the following syntax; `~/.config/sysinfo/sysinfo.sh -n pulseaudio -a cyan`. The reason I do have a wrapper script is I use these scripts across different setups.

Some other tools allow to custom set environment variables; so I do some customization of environment variables. (For example; the `sysinfo.sh -n <name>` is analogous to `name=<name> sysinfo.sh`)

## Why does polybar need this feature?
This would help users organize their custom scripts; as there can be one main block like the following;

```
[module/skeleton]
type = custom/script
tail = true
interval = 0
label = %output%
format = <label>
exec = ~/.config/sysinfo/sysinfo.sh
```

And then each custom script section could be defined like following;

```
[module/clock-script]
inherit = module/skeleton
environment = 'name=clock accent=cyan'
```
Which would make the config file more modular and organized.

## Describe the solution you'd like
Add a config option `environment` to a script that gets parsed to the beginning of a custom script's exec line.

## Describe alternatives you've considered
I currently read command line arguments; but it takes more work to do so.

## Additional context
Not really a vital or needed improvement; but I was thinking it could be trivial to implement.
author: bbaserdem

comments.body:
We've had lots of people asking about something like this before. Most the of their use-cases could be addressed by either adding the env variable to the script or into the polybar launch script.

But this is an interesting use-case.
A workaround for this could be:

```
exec = env name=clock accent=cyan ~/.config/sysinfo/sysinfo.sh
```

But you would still need to write the script path every time.
I am still unsure if we really want this in polybar. It will undoubtedly be useful, but if we add it here, we may also need to add it to the ipc hooks and click actions.

I also don't quite see a good way to implement this. We could execute the command with `/bin/sh -c "env ${environment} ${exec}"`, but this changes how `exec` is executed and won't work for things like `exec = cmd1; cmd2`

The other option would be to parse the `environment` value to extract key value pairs, but this becomes less trivial, as we would need to be able to parse things like 

```dosini
environment = FOO="ab " BAR="\"cd ef\""
```

Which is a bit more difficult than just splitting on each space. I'm not sure if that's worth the hassle.

Someone asked on IRC about this and somehow I missed the most obvious solution to the problem I described in my last comment: Let the user define `env-*` config options. For example, `env-FOO="ab"` would set the `FOO` env variable. We can then set that variable using `setenv()` after forking. This avoids all the issues around shell escaping.
Is this issue taken? I would like to work on this.
I am not aware of anyone working on this. I assigned it to you, go ahead :)

the feature added in response to this issue works for the custom script when it is called from the `exec` line in the module, however the `env-FOO` vars are NOT passed to the custom script if it's invoked with `click-left`, `click-middle` or `click-right`. Would you consider this an omission / bug in the original implementation or a separate feature request? I think principal of least surprise is that the environment variables are passed from the click events too.

This would definitely be a separate feature. Click commands are handled in a completely different way than the `exec` command.
When a click command is executed, polybar doesn't even know which module it came from, so something like this would require some bigger changes (it would also mean all click commands in all modules could support env variables).

title: Xworkspaces: active desktop detect error
body:
## Describe the issue
I'm using i3wm with polybar.

When I work at workspace 3, open an app, like Firefox, 
Firefox has an i3 config: for_window move container to workspace 2
So firefox should run in workspace 2, and i3 still work at workspace 3.

The problem is : xworkspaces module  will highlight workspace 2 as active.

**Expected behavior:**
xworkspaces should still highlight at workspace 3, which is the really activating workspace.

## To Reproduce
Go workspace 3
Open Firefox with i3config  for_window [class="Firefox"] move container to workspace 2

## Environment:
* WM: i3 i3 version 4.11 (2015-09-30, branch "4.11") © 2009 Michael Stapelberg and contributors
* Distro: ubuntu 16.04
* Output of `polybar -vvv`:
polybar 3.3.0-44-g82b9ea8
Features: +alsa +curl +i3 +mpd +network(libnl) +pulseaudio +xkeyboard

## Additional context
I found the problem in xworkspaces module code:
In function rebuild_desktop_states,
   if (d->index == m_current_desktop) 
this line used to check whether this desktop is actived.

This is the problem:
 When I have workspace [1,3], active at workspace 3, m_desktop_names will be : ['1','3'] and m_current_desktop == 1.

Then I launch a app in workspace 2, but still stay in workspace 3. m_desktop_names will be updated to ['1','2','3'] by get_desktop_names, BUT m_current_desktop still be 1. 
So, xworkspaces think workspace 2 is the active one.

I add a string variable m_desktop_current_name, recording the current dekstop name.
Then use 
 if (m_desktop_current_name == m_desktop_names[m_current_desktop]) 
to check active workspace, 
The problem fixed.
author: DrunkenChicken

comments.body:
Good catch, was able to reproduce. You are also correct that we should not use workspace indices to identify workspaces but rather their names.

Would you mind submitting a PR with your fix?

title: Conventions and guidelines
body:
As the project is growing I think it would be good to introduce some conventions and guidelines to keep everything a bit more uniform.

For example:
* Coding guidelines
* Merge strategy (e.g. `--ff-only`)
* Conventions of git messages

It's possible to add verification to travis-ci that would automate the process.

Any thoughts?
author: jaagr

comments.body:
I think that's a great idea.

Also I think we should make a rule that even us maintainers should only use PRs to change the codebase. Right now this is already happening for bigger features and stuff, but I think we should do this for all changes. Like this we would have a dedicated space for each change, it's easier for everyone to keep track or what's happening and why and this also allows us to group a set of changes together. This can also be used to make sure that no commit fails a travis build.

For coding guidelines it would probably be good to add a pre commit hook that automatically formats the code to conform to certain style guidelines.
I don't think having many coding rules is wise because it would add a lot of overhead for first-time contributors and it probably wouldn't help the readability of the code that much.

Can `--ff-only` be forced in a github PR or would we have to merge PRs on the command line?

Yeah I totally agree about forcing pull-requests for everyone. I think that can be fixed by changing the repository settings. I will have a look.

I'm generally against applying changes automatically when performing an action (e.g. reformatting the code upon commit) but a travis check using for example `clang-format` could hint the contributor that the committed code needs to be changed.

I agree that it's not a good idea to add alot of overhead for first-timers but some restrictions is, in my opinion, needed to maintain the quality. A `clang-format` check does of course not ensure the quality of the contributed code but it's a start to keep the code uniform.

I will investigate your question regarding `--ff-only`.
I removed the ability to merge pull-requests using `--no-ff` (configured in the repository settings).

There's no way to block changes, done by contributors, to the default branch from what I can see in the settings. But we are still a low number of contributors so for now I guess we could agree that we create a PR for all changes. And of course the owner of the PR is not allowed to merge.

Yeah maybe we could add a separate travis check just for `clang-format`

Just agreeing on PRs only will probably suffice. For small PRs, I think that we could allow people to merge their own PRs, if it really messes things up, it's easy to undo the whole PR at once.

While I have you here, can you add us to the xpp and i3ipcpp repos?

Regarding small PR's: I still think we should have a requirement of at least 1 approval (unfortunately I don't think we can enforce it by a GitHub setting). After that you could of course merge it yourself.

Yeah, of course, I'll add you as contributors there as well.
I have added all polybar contributors to the lib forks (xpp, i3icpp).
Should we have a todo list of some kind? We could possibly create a kanban board under Projects and manage stuff there.
We could also open a PR which contains those guidelines written down and we could then track everything over there. What do you think would be better?

I've been considering using Projects as a centralized location to manage feature requests/enhancements, so we could possibly include this over there, and convert it into a PR when we're ready.

Should this be under CONTRIBUTING.md?

Having feature requests in a centralized location will certainly help us keep track of them better and not let them slip through the cracks. How would discussions work in a setup like that? Can we do that inside the Project or would still need to use an issue or PR for this?

From what I've seen, if a card doesn't have an issue yet, there is an option to convert it into an issue, so discussions should occur there. Existing PRs and issues can be added as-is.

title: --reload doesn't monitor include-files
body: When using the flag `--reload` if a file has been included with `include-file` and edited the bar will not be updated with the new settings.
author: bricewge

comments.body: This seems to have been forgotten when the `include-file` option was introduced, I'll take a look at it
